1.66.text:
From a distance, philosophy seems weird, irrelevant,
boring...

6.00.text: and yet also – just a little – intriguing.

8.54.text: But what are philosophers really for?

11.17.text:
The answer is, handily, already contained
in the word philosophy itself.

16.38.text:
In Ancient Greek, philo means love
and sophia means wisdom.

20.52.text: Philosophers are people devoted to wisdom.

23.61.text: Being wise means attempting to live and die well.

26.84.text:
In their pursuit of wisdom, philosophers have
developed a very

29.67.text:
specific skill-set. They have, over the centuries,
become experts in

34.25.text:
many of the things that make people not very
wise. Five stand out:

43.04.text:
There are lots of big questions around: What
is the meaning of life?

46.27.text: What's a job for? How should society be arranged?

49.94.text:
Most of us entertain them every now and then,
but we despair of trying

53.00.text:
to answer them. They have the status of jokes.
We call them

56.66.text:
'pretentious'. But they matter deeply because
only with sound answers

60.48.text: to them can we direct our energies meaningfully.

64.11.text:
Philosophers are people unafraid of asking
questions. They have, over

67.76.text:
the centuries, asked the very largest. They
realise that these

71.06.text:
questions can always be broken down into more
manageable chunks and

74.63.text:
that the only really pretentious thing is
to think one is above

83.39.text:
Public opinion – or what gets called ‘common
sense’ – is sensible and

87.23.text:
reasonable in countless areas. It’s what
you hear about from friends

90.54.text:
and neighbours, the stuff you take in without
even thinking about it.

93.75.text:
But common sense is also often full of daftness
and error.

98.50.text:
Philosophy gets us to submit all aspects of
common sense to reason.

102.44.text:
It wants us to think for ourselves. Is it really
true what people say

106.43.text:
about love, money, children, travel, work?
Philosophers are interested

110.54.text:
in asking whether an idea is logical – rather
than simply assuming it

114.31.text: must be right because it is popular and long-established.

120.50.text:
We’re not very good at knowing what goes
on in our own minds.

123.22.text: Someone we meet is very annoying, but we can’t pin down what the issue is.

127.21.text: Or we lose our temper, but can’t readily tell what we’re so cross about.

131.09.text:
We lack insight into our own satisfactions
and dislikes.

134.36.text:
That’s why we need to examine our own minds.
Philosophy is committed

138.45.text:
to self-knowledge – and its central precept
– articulated by the

142.74.text:
earliest, greatest philosopher, Socrates – is
just two words long:

150.65.text:
We’re not very good at making ourselves
happy. We overrate the power

154.23.text:
of some things to improve our lives – and
underrate others.

157.65.text: We make the wrong choices because, guided by advertising and false glamour,

161.72.text: we keep on imagining that a particular kind of holiday, or car, or computer

165.56.text: will make a bigger difference than it can.

168.08.text:
At the same time, we underestimate the contribution
of other things –

171.26.text:
like going for a walk - which may have little
prestige but can

174.58.text: contribute deeply to the character of existence.

178.23.text:
Philosophers seek to be wise by getting more
precise about the

180.80.text:
activities and attitudes that really can help
our lives to go better.

188.32.text:
Philosophers are good at keeping a sense of
what really matters and what doesn't.

192.00.text:
On hearing the news that he’d
lost all his possessions in a shipwreck,

195.52.text:
the Stoic philosopher Zeno
simply said:

197.76.text: ‘Fortune commands me to be a less encumbered philosopher.’

201.68.text: It’s responses like these that have made the very term ‘philosophical’

205.66.text: a byword for calm, long-term thinking and strength-of-mind,

211.96.text:
The wisdom of philosophy is – in modern
times – mostly delivered in

215.20.text:
the form of books. But in the past, philosophers
sat in market squares

219.41.text:
and discussed their ideas with shopkeepers
or went into government

222.40.text:
offices and palaces to give advice. It wasn’t
abnormal to have a

225.86.text:
philosopher on the payroll. Philosophy was
thought of as a normal,

229.66.text:
basic activity – rather than as an unusual,
esoteric, optional extra.

234.42.text:
Nowadays, it’s not so much that we overtly
deny this thought but we

238.59.text:
just don’t have the right institutions set
up to promulgate wisdom

242.17.text:
coherently in the world. In the future, though,
when the value of

246.42.text:
philosophy is a little clearer, we can expect
to meet more

249.26.text:
philosophers in daily life. They won’t be
locked up, living mainly in

252.86.text:
university departments, because the points
at which our unwisdom bites

256.97.text:
– and messes up our lives – are multiple
and urgently need attention -
